Award.AwardTitle: One Year After Science's Grand Challenges in Education: Professional Empowerment of STEM Teachers' Through Education Policy and Decision Making

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Following up on a special issue of Science (August 2013) that identified several Grand Challenges in Science Education, this project proposes a convocation to more deeply explore those challenges that are particularly relevant for K-12 teachers and highlights the roles teachers can play on issues vital to the improvement of K-12 STEM education.

The convocation will: (1) pull together the evidence base on whether involving teachers in education policy and decision-making leads to improvements in policies; (2) identify the models of teacher engagement at the national, state, and local levels that currently exist; and (3) identify the kinds of communication efforts, resources and other activities that are needed to help policymakers better understand the role of teachers in these processes. The convocation addresses several important and timely questions: (1) how to help teachers engage in important education issues beyond their classrooms, and (2) what kinds of networks or mechanisms might be identified to accomplish that engagement.

Following the meeting, materials will be developed that will be available both in hard copy and as PDF files from the National Academies Press.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recent economic conditions and the performance of U.S. students on national and international assessments in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) have caused policymakers and politicians to focus attention on many aspects of K-12 STEM, including the quality and effectiveness of classroom teachers and their preparation, professional development, evaluation, compensation and collective bargaining, and career advancement. However, one critical set of voices in this discussion largely has been missing--that of classroom teachers themselves. To explore how the voices and leadership of STEM teachers might be better integrated into such conversations at the local, state, and national levels, under the aegis of the Teacher Advisory Council of the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine (National Academies) a committee of teachers and other education experts organized a convocation in 2014 that brought together a broad spectrum of education experts, policymakers, representatives from government agencies, private foundations, and teacher leaders and organizations that support them. The intellectual merit of this convening was that it enabled these attendees to examine some of the research literature on the ways that teachers can contribute to education policy- and decision making and how the knowledge, perspectives, and professional experiences of teachers can contribute to and inform discussions about some of the nation’s most compelling and difficult issues in STEM education.

 

The convocation led to the publication of a National Academies report, Exploring Opportunities for STEM Teacher Leadership and a brief summary of the report. These documents have resulted in several significant broader impacts:

-        As of April 10, 2017 the report has been downloaded more than 3,800 times from the website of the National Academies Press.

-        These documents have led to multiple discussions about STEM teacher leadership in a variety of settings, including meetings of teacher professional organizations such as the 2016 and 2017 National Science Teachers Association annual meetings in Nashville, TN and Los Angeles, CA, a meeting of principal investigators in STEM education with grants from NSF, and through a keynote presentation to the 2016 cohort of Presidential Awardees for Excellence in Mathematics and Science Teaching in Washington, DC.

-        This report served as a catalyst for the Teacher Advisory Council to organize another convocation in Washington, DC on September 30 and October 1, 2016 that examined potential roles for K-12 teacher leaders around policy- and decision making around the implementation of engineering education in Grades K-12. More than 1000 people, half of whom are teacher leaders, participated in this event Increasing the Roles and Significance of Teachers in Policymaking for K-12 Engineering Education: Proceedings of a Convocation was released March, 2017 and is available for free downloading. The convocation was sponsored by 100Kin10 with supplemental support from the Samueli Foundation.
